questiontext.text:
Logical Connectives

We have already introduced the idea of mathematical statements in the previous section and we have seen that mathematical arguments and proofs are a series of mathematical statements that follow logically from each other. However, what do we mean specifically by 'following logically'? This is what we will examine in this section. Mathematics is a language that we need to learn in order to communicate it separately. One of the barriers to writing proof is understanding and using this language. Mathematics uses a series of logical symbols as shorthand for the equivalent English statements.

Consider the following statements:

  • I will go outside today.
  • I will go outside tomorrow.

These are two separate statements, however we have the tools in the English language in order to combine these statements. For example we could write

  • I will go outside today and I will go outside tomorrow.
  • I will go outside today or I will go outside tomorrow.
  • I will go outside today then I will go outside tomorrow.

Each of these is a form of logical connective and they have important uses in mathematics. In order to link mathematical statements together we have to use a series of such logical connectives. The most common forms of logical connectives are listed in the table below.

We have previously used some of the symbols in our calculations but these are their formal definitions. In mathematics we illustrate the use of these connectives by the use of variables e.g. \(A,B,C\).

Â 

Example

Write the statement "\((A \wedge B) \implies C"\) in English.

Convert the statement "If \(x\) is positive then the square root of \(x\) is real".

Solution

We can use the table of connectives to make these conversions. The first statement reads:

\(A\) and \(B\) implies \(C\).

We will talk more about implications in a later section.

To convert the second statement, we have to replace the statement with the logical symbols from the table. The statement becomes:

\(x>0 \implies \sqrt{x} \in \mathbb{R}\).

Here, \(\mathbb{R}\) is the symbol for the real numbers and \(\in\) means 'is an element of'.
